name: Idra - Open Data Federation Platform
description: Idra is a web application able to federate existing Open Data Management Systems (ODMS) based on different technologies providing a unique access point to search and discover open datasets coming from heterogeneous sources. Idra uniforms representation of collected open datasets, thanks to the adoption of international standards (DCAT-AP) and provides a set of RESTful APIs to be used by third party applications.

name: eve
description:
EVE-OS
EVE aims to develop an open, agnostic and standardized architecture unifying the approach to developing and orchestrating cloud-native applications across the enterprise on-premises edge. It offers users new levels of control through hardware-assisted virtualization of on-prem edge devices. Once installed, EVE has direct access to and control of underlying resources and provides standard APIs that allow more efficient use of resources and can effectively partition hardware to increase workload consolidation and application multi-tenancy.

EVE supports both ARM and Intel architectures and requires hardware-assisted virtualization. While EVE can run on a board as small as a $20 Orange Pi, the sweet spot for its deployment are IoT Gateways and Industrial PCs.

To get its job done, EVE leverages a lot of great open source projects: Xen Project, Linuxkit and Alpine Linux just to name a few. All of that functionality is being orchestrated by the Go microservices available under pkg/pillar. Why pillar? Well, because pillar is the kind of a monolith we need to break out into true, individual microservices under pkg/.

name: Cloud Native Buildpacks
description: The Cloud Native Buildpacks project provides tooling to transform source code into container images using modular, reusable build functions called buildpacks. To accomplish this, the project takes advantage of advanced features in the OCI image standard.

description_good_justification:
The Cloud Native Buildpacks project provides tooling to transform source code into container images using modular, reusable build functions called buildpacks. To accomplish this, the project takes advantage of advanced features in the OCI image standard such as cross-repository blob mounting and image layer "rebasing" on Docker API v2 registries.

https://buildpacks.io/

know_common_errors_justification: The primary developers of the project are familiar with secure software design.
crypto_published_justification: The project uses only cryptographic protocols and algorithms that are publicly published.
crypto_call_justification: The project does not reimplement its own cryptographic functions.
crypto_floss_justification: All functionality in the project that depends on crypto uses FLOSS.
crypto_working_justification: The project does not depend on broken cryptographic algorithms.
crypto_password_storage_justification: The project does not depend on key agreement protocols.
delivery_mitm_justification: Software is released with digitally signed packages as mitigation of attacks on the distribution system. Signed with GitHub’s verified signature.
delivery_unsigned_justification: The project's signed metadata, which includes cryptographic hashes, is always validated by the client software before accepting it.

static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Codeql static analysis setup for buildpacks/pack and there are plans to extend its usage to buildpacks/lifecycle in the near term: https://github.com/buildpacks/pack/blob/main/.github/workflows/codeql-analysis.yml
static_analysis_often_justification: All pull requests and the most recent commit are automatically analyzed by GolangCI.
dynamic_analysis_justification: Project is nterested in leveraging fuzzing and other dynamic code analysis tools in the future.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: The project's default security mechanisms do not depend on weak algorithms or modes.
discussion_justification: Discussions take place on the project's GitHub issue tracker.
english_justification: All of project's material is written in English, and it accepts bug reports and comments in English. All responses to other questions on the individual types of documentation include links to pages in English.

dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: Need to enable dynamic code analysis tool as part of the OSC CII process, in the interim contributing company performs a security review of the code prior to being checked into the O-RAN site

name: lxd-compose
description: LXD Compose
contribution_justification: Projects on GitHub by default use issues and pull requests, as encouraged by documentation such as <https://guides.github.com/activities/contributing-to-open-source/>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/MottainaiCI/lxd-compose/blob/master/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The GPL-3.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: https://github.com/MottainaiCI/lxd-compose-docs
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
enhancement_responses_justification: https://github.com/MottainaiCI/lxd-compose/issues look for those tagged as Feature.
build_floss_tools_justification: Makefile + Go is all that's needed
test_policy_justification: All features get their own section in the testsuite.
warnings_justification: Static analysis is run on all code. Go doesn't have much compiler flags we can use to do build time checks.
warnings_fixed_justification: Go doesn't issue warnings but all static analysis warnings are critical so must be resolved prior to tests passing.
warnings_strict_justification: All our linter outputs are considered critical and will prevent a branch from landing.
know_secure_design_justification: The software is based on LXD code that is considered written following best practices.
know_common_errors_justification:
Go's design avoids a lot of the common security issues with some other compiled languages (buffer overflows, uninitialized pointers, ...). Our linters catch some of the more subtle issues and manual review is done on all submitted code.

Whenever possible, code is run after privilege dropping and we use kernel capabilities, apparmor, seccomp, cgroups and namespaces to reduce the attack surface of the code we run to a minimum.
crypto_call_justification: We use the Go TLS library.
crypto_keylength_justification: LXD code uses hardcoded default of 4096bit RSA.
crypto_working_justification: All broken ciphers are disabled, only 4 very recent and safe ciphers are whitelisted.
crypto_password_storage_justification: We don't have a concept of a user but when a password is used, it is hashed using scrypt.
crypto_random_justification: Handled by Go TLS which uses /dev/random as its source.
delivery_mitm_justification: https with client certificate authentication and either validates the trust chain to the system CA or the expected certificate has to be explicitly trusted by the user.
delivery_unsigned_justification: All hashes (for images in our case) are retrieved over https, the actual payload may then be downloaded over http, hashed and checked against the hash we got earlier.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
